text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC here at hinkle fieldhouse on the
campus of Butler University in
Indianapolis the day of crucial
primaries in the Democratic race both
Indiana and North Carolina will go to
the polls almost 200 delegates at stake
in the race Barack Obama remains the
front-runner he's within 300 delegates
of locking up the Democratic nomination
but Hillary Clinton still has a chance
if she can perform very well in these
and the states to follow of the next
several weeks to change the dynamics of
the race convince some of those
uncommitted super-delegates that she is
the stronger candidate in November late
polls show her drawing closer to Barack
Obama who leads in North Carolina but
building a lead of her own in the state
of Indiana want to bring in John Broder
of the New York Times who's been with
the Hillary Clinton campaign over the
last several days John what's the feel
with Hillary Clinton as she rolls toward
Election Day well it's hard to imagine
that you're looking at a and a candidate
who's trailing in pledged delegates
who's trailing in popular vote because
she's running like a part runner but
she's running hard she's drawing
decent-sized crowds they're very
enthusiastic and she's drawing as much
energy from them as they from her she
seems to be having a better time at this
point in the race she's been down she's
fighting back what is the sense of how
Hillary Clinton is enjoying this face
because there were points early in the
campaign where she didn't seem to be
having a great time on the campaign
trail well certainly her loss in Iowa
came as a shock the performance on Super
Tuesday which was lower than everybody's
expectations including hers really set
her back but she came roaring back in
ohio and texas really put herself back
in the game and like her husband bill
she she seems to perform best when our
backs against the wall do you get a
sense from the crowds or from other
people that you talked to of exactly why
she seems to be coming back certainly in
Indiana where we started out tide is it
Jeremiah Wright is it this debate over
the gas tax holiday where he's against
it she's for it those two factors are
clearly important I think Jeremiah
Wright
performance recently in Washington gave
a lot of voters pause even supporters of
Barack Obama that maybe we don't know as
much about this this phenom as we
thought we did Hillary Clinton's gas tax
holiday in which the oil companies would
essentially pay the 18 cents a gallon
that Americans pay in federal gasoline
taxes over the summer is definitely very
popular with voters it even though it's
not going anywhere in Congress and
economists generally oppose it but she's
also enjoying a benefit from her own
feistiness out on the campaign trail
she's a fighter she's doing well under
very difficult circumstances and people
respect that seems like it's been a
while since we've talked about mistakes
by Bill Clinton he seems to be
connecting with some of these rural
audiences is that a big asset for her
it's a huge asset for her whether that
translates into enough votes
particularly in North Carolina where
he's been working the small towns very
heavily we won't know until tonight but
we will know tonight he's done probably
50 events in the state of Indiana mostly
in the smaller towns and these are
places where she runs up big margins in
places like Pennsylvania and Ohio and we
expect her to hear to John one of the
things that we've seen in the exit polls
throughout the primary campaign Barack
Obama's done better with secular voters
you've spent some time with the guy in
charge of the Hillary Clinton campaigns
outreach to religious religiously minded
Democrats tell me about how effective
he's been what sort of audience he's
fighting well this is a fellow named
burn Strider he's from a small town in
Mississippi he's been helping the
Democrats for the last eight or nine
years particularly in Congress try to
connect with religious voters those
so-called Values Voters that the
Republicans have grabbed away from the
Democrat
over the last couple of decades and he
seems to be doing a quite a good job in
connecting particularly in some of these
small towns in the rural South he by he
seats seeks out pastors and small church
leaders and talks to them and tries to
bring their flocks in get them
registered to vote for a Democrat and
particularly for Hillary Clinton it
seems to be working again the numbers
it's hard to tell does Obama have a
comparable effort Obama has a comparable
effort and he too has a great appeal to
the faith voter however the Jeremiah
Wright thing makes him feel a little bit
out of the mainstream that he comes out
of a black religious tradition rather
than an American more broadly based
church tradition he has a director of
religious outreach to but the effort
isn't quite as obvious as hers you
mentioned black voters of course that's
been a tremendous strength for Barack
Obama in state after States getting
eighty to ninety percent of the
african-american vote one of the
questions about North Carolina and
whether Hillary Clinton could actually
upset Barack Obama is can he cut into
the african-american vote which is very
large in North Carolina much larger than
here in Indiana do we see any signs of
that signs that Hillary's no I'm sorry
that yes that Hillary Clinton is making
progress with african-american voters as
she makes progress with other groups in
the electric I'm not sure that that's
been measured in the polls yet but
there's sort of a feeling on the ground
yesterday I went to two events of
Hillary's and the the crowds were
surprisingly racially mixed I would say
maybe no more than ten or fifteen
percent african-american but that's more
than you've been seeing in many of these
other states you seldom saw a black
voter in Ohio I had a Hillary Clinton
rally in a Pennsylvania Hillary Clinton
rally even here in Indiana but in North
Carolina where they comprise something
close to forty percent of the electorate
you're seeing some of them at least
drifting over to take a look at what
she's saying John thanks for joining us
my pleasure the polls are already open
they open at six that will close at six
pm eastern time in most of Indiana which
means we'll get a fairly early result
from the Indiana voting tonight North
Carolina results will come in a little
bit later we'll keep you posted on
nytimes.com
